Provision Text: Between

The First Nations set out in Schedule A
  as represented by their respective Ogiimak
  (hereinafter referred to as the "First Nations")
and

The Anishinabek Nation as represented by the Grand Council Ogiimah of the
  Anishinabek Nation/President of the Union of Ontario Indians,
  (hereinafter referred to as the "Anishinabek Nation")
and

Her Majesty the Queen in Right of Canada
  as represented by the Minister of Crown-Indigenous Relations,
  (hereinafter referred to as "Canada")

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: (Preamble to the Anishinaabe Chi-Naaknigewin)

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Debenjiged gii'saan anishinaaben akiing giibi dgwon gaadeni mnidoo waadiziwin.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Creator placed the Anishinaabe on the earth along with the gift of spirituality.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Shkode, nibi, aki, noodin, giibi dgosdoonan wii naagdowendmang maanpii shkagmigaang.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Here on mother earth, there were gifts given to the Anishinaabe to look after, fire, water, earth and wind.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Debenjiged gii miinaan gechtwaa wendaagog Anishinaaben waa naagdoonjin ninda niizhwaaswi kino maadwinan.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: The Creator also gave the Anishinaabe seven sacred gifts to guide them.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: They are:

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Zaagidwin, Debwewin, Mnaadendmowin, Nbwaakaawin, Dbaadendiziwin, Gwekwaadziwin miinwa Aakedhewin.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Love, Truth, Respect, Wisdom, Humility, Honesty and Bravery.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Debenjiged kiimiingona dedbinwe wi naagdowendiwin.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Creator gave us sovereignty to govern ourselves.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Ka mnaadendanaa gaabi zhiwebag miinwaa nango megwaa ezhwebag, miinwa geyaabi waa ni zhiwebag.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: We respect and honour the past, present and future.

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the First Nations assert that, together as aboriginal peoples of the Ojibway, Chippewa, Odawa, Pottowatomi, Algonquin, Nipissing, Delaware and Mississauga Tribal Nations who share a sense of aboriginal identity and spirituality and are united through historic origin, values, language, traditions and culture, they are among the First Nations comprising the Anishinabek Nation

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the First Nations assert that their Tribal Nations maintained self-sufficient governments with sustainable economies, distinctive languages, powerful spirituality and diverse cultures within a defined territory which pre-existed the establishment of Canada and that these Tribal Nations continue to exist

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the First Nations assert that they have a sacred duty to ensure the well-being of the people to the Seventh Generation and that it is incumbent upon the leadership of the First Nations to ensure this sacred duty is honoured

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the special and historic relationship between aboriginal peoples and Canada is evidenced by, among other things, the treaties and this relationship continues and it is recognized in the Constitution of Canada

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas Canada recognizes the importance of strengthening its relationships with First Nations

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the Parties recognize and respect the solemn and enduring nature of the treaties and the importance to Canada and the First Nations of honouring the treaties

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the existing aboriginal and treaty rights of the aboriginal peoples of Canada are recognized and affirmed by section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas Canada recognizes the inherent right of self-government as an existing aboriginal right within section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas Canada's recognition of the inherent right of self-government as an existing aboriginal right within section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982 is based on the view that the aboriginal peoples of Canada have the right to govern themselves and to make their own decisions in relation to matters that are integral to their unique cultures, identities, traditions, languages and institutions and with respect to their special relationship to their land and their resources

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the Parties acknowledge that an assertion by 1 Party is an expression of that Party's position and does not represent acceptance of that position by the other Parties to the negotiations

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Whereas the First Nations were represented by the Union of Ontario Indians in the negotiation of this Agreement

Section:
Ngo Dwe Waangizid Anishinaabe
      One Anishinaabe Family
Provision Text: Therefore, the First Nations, the Anishinabek Nation and Canada agree as follows:
The following definitions apply in this Agreement:
"Agreement" means this Anishinabek Nation Governance Agreement
"Anishinaabe Institution" means a government institution established pursuant to a First Nation law or other authority, or an Anishinabek Nation law or other authority under this Agreement
"Anishinabek Nation" means the collectivity of First Nations set out in Schedule A of this Agreement
"Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement" means the education agreement between the First Nations of that agreement and Canada
"Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement" means the agreement described in Chapter 8 of this Agreement
"Anishinabek Nation Government" means the government of the Anishinabek Nation represented by the Grand Council
"Conflict" means an actual conflict in operation or operational incompatibility

"Decision" means a decision made by a First Nation Government, the Anishinabek Nation Government or an Anishinaabe Institution pursuant to an exercise of law-making power or other authority under this Agreement
"Deputy Grand Council Ogiimah" means a Deputy Grand Council Chief of the Anishinabek Nation
"Deputy Grand Council Ogiimak" means the Deputy Grand Council Chiefs of the Anishinabek Nation
"E'Dbendaagzijig" means a person who is a citizen of a First Nation as defined in that First Nation's E'Dbendaagzijig law
"Effective Date" means the date that this Agreement comes into legal effect under federal legislation
"Federally Supported Programs and Services" means the list of programs and services described in the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement
"First Nation" means, depending on the context, a First Nation who:

is a Party to this Agreement as set out in Schedule A
          or
is a "band" for the purposes of the continuing application of the Indian Act
"First Nations' Fiscal Contribution" means the amount determined pursuant to the formula set out in the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement and used in the calculation of the Transfer Payment
"First Nation Government" means the government of a First Nation represented by its Ogiimah and council

"Generally Accepted Accounting Principles" means the accounting principles generally accepted in Canada from time to time, and, where the Chartered Professional Accountants of Canada or its successor publishes a statement of a principle or an accounting guideline, including the CPA Canada Public Sector Accounting Handbook, that statement or guideline will be considered conclusively to be an accounting principle or guideline generally accepted in Canada

"Grand Council" means the law-making body of the Anishinabek Nation and is comprised of a Grand Council Ogiimah, Deputy Grand Council Ogiimak and a representative of each First Nation of the Anishinabek Nation, all of whom must be E'Dbendaagzijig of the Anishinabek Nation
"Grand Council Ogiimah" means the Grand Council Chief of the Anishinabek Nation
"Implementation and Operations Committee" means the committee established pursuant to Chapter 16 of this Agreement
"Implementation Plan" means the plan described in Chapter 16 of this Agreement

"Intellectual Property" means any intangible property right resulting from intellectual activity in the industrial, scientific, literary, or artistic fields, including any right relating to patents, copyrights, trademarks, industrial designs or plant breeders' rights
"International Legal Obligation" means an obligation binding on Canada under international law, including an obligation that is in force on or after the Effective Date
"International Treaty" means an international agreement concluded:

between states
          or

between one or more states and one or more international organizations
          in written form and governed by international law, whether embodied in a single instrument or in 2 or more related instruments and whatever its particular designation

"International Tribunal" means any international court, tribunal, committee, panel or other international body, mechanism or procedure, which has competence to determine or advise on Canada's compliance with an International Legal Obligation
"Ogiimah" means a Chief of a First Nation of the Anishinabek Nation
"Ogiimak" means the Chiefs of the First Nations of the Anishinabek Nation
"Parties" means the individual First Nations, the Anishinabek Nation and Canada
"Reserve" means:
a "reserve" as defined in the Indian Act of a First Nation
lands set apart by Canada in the future as a "reserve"
"Transfer Payment" means the monetary amount, payable by Canada, calculated pursuant to the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement
"Union of Ontario Indians" means the body incorporated under the laws of the Province of Ontario or its successor
This Agreement is governed by, construed and interpreted in accordance with the laws in force in the Province of Ontario.
For greater certainty, the Federal Court has jurisdiction to hear questions in relation to the interpretation or application of this Agreement.
In this Agreement:
headings or sub-headings are for convenience only and do not form a part of this Agreement and in no way define, limit, alter or enlarge the scope or meaning of any provision

a reference to a law includes any portion of that law and every amendment to it, every regulation or any portion of the regulation and any order made under it and any law enacted in substitution or in replacement of it
unless otherwise clear from the context, wherever the singular is used, it will include the plural, and the use of the plural includes the singular
unless otherwise clear from the context, the use of the word "including" means "including, but not limited to" and the use of the word "includes" means "includes, but is not limited to"
unless otherwise clear from the context, a reference to a chapter, section, sub-section or schedule refers to a chapter, section, sub-section or schedule of this Agreement

the word "or" is used in its inclusive sense, such that, depending on the context, it could mean A or B, it could also mean A as well as B but not C, and it could also mean A as well as B as well as C and the word "and" is used in its joint sense meaning A and B and C but not any alone

the word "will" denotes an obligation that, unless this Agreement provides to the contrary, must be carried out as soon as practicable once the relevant time becomes of the essence and "may" is permissive
The Statutory Instruments Act does not apply to the laws of the First Nations or the Anishinabek Nation.
This Agreement provides for:
the establishment of an Anishinabek Nation Government with the power to enact laws and to address matters of common concern to First Nations
the establishment of a new government-to-government relationship between the Parties within the framework of the Constitution Act, 1982
the exercise of certain law-making powers and other authorities by the First Nations and the Anishinabek Nation

the power of the First Nation Governments and the Anishinabek Nation Government to establish institutions, procedures and processes which help promote effective governance, economic prosperity, social well-being and healthy communities
the establishment of a new intergovernmental financial relationship and fiscal arrangements to support the exercise of law-making powers and other authorities under this Agreement
its implementation
a framework for negotiating future self-government agreements between the Parties
other related matters

This Agreement is based on the recognition that the inherent right of self-government is an existing aboriginal right within the meaning of section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982, without the Parties taking any position with respect to how an inherent right of self-government may be ultimately defined at law.
This Agreement is not a treaty within the meaning of section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982.
Nothing in this Agreement will be construed:

so as to abrogate or derogate from the aboriginal or treaty rights of the Aboriginal peoples of Canada recognized and affirmed by section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982
          or
as satisfaction or fulfillment of any treaty obligations of Canada
For greater certainty, nothing in this Agreement will determine or define any Aboriginal or treaty rights of the First Nations.
Nothing in this Agreement confers or denies, or is intended to confer or deny, rights of entry into Canada or grant Canadian citizenship.
The fiduciary relationship between Canada and each First Nation will continue after the Effective Date.

As a First Nation exercises law-making power and other authority under this Agreement, fiduciary obligations of Canada to that First Nation will be as determined by jurisprudence respecting fiduciary relationships and fiduciary obligations.

Section: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Provision Text: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms applies to each First Nations Government and the Anishinabek Nation Government in respect of all matters within their authority.
A First Nation is not liable for anything done or omitted to be done by Canada or any person or entity authorized to act on behalf of Canada for matters:
where there is no First Nation law-making power or other authority set out in this Agreement

where there has been no exercise of First Nation law-making power or other authority set out in this Agreement
          or
related to or arising from this Agreement and which occurred before the Effective Date
The Anishinabek Nation is not liable in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by Canada or any person or entity authorized to act on behalf of Canada for matters:
where there is no Anishinabek Nation law-making power or other authority set out in this Agreement

where there has been no exercise of Anishinabek Nation law-making power or other authority set out in this Agreement
          or
related to or arising from this Agreement and which occurred before the Effective Date

Canada is not liable in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by a First Nation or any person or entity authorized to act on behalf of a First Nation for matters relating to a law-making power or other authority set out in this Agreement after a First Nation has exercised that law-making power or other authority.

Canada is not liable in respect of anything done or omitted to be done by the Anishinabek Nation or any person or entity authorized to act on behalf of the Anishinabek Nation for matters relating to a law-making power or other authority set out in this Agreement after the Anishinabek Nation has exercised that law-making power or other authority.
Canada will indemnify a First Nation for any damage, cost, loss or liability suffered by that First Nation as a result of an act or omission described in section 3.9.
Canada will indemnify the Anishinabek Nation for any damage, cost, loss or liability suffered by the Anishinabek Nation as a result of an act or omission described in section 3.10.
A First Nation will indemnify Canada for any damage, cost, loss or liability suffered by Canada as a result of an act or omission described in section 3.11.
The Anishinabek Nation will indemnify Canada for any damage, cost, loss or liability suffered by Canada as a result of an act or omission described in section 3.12.
A party that is the subject of a claim, demand, action, or other proceeding that may give rise to a requirement to indemnify pursuant to this Agreement:
will vigorously defend the claim, demand, action, or other proceeding

will not settle or compromise the claim, demand, action, or other proceeding except with the consent of the party that granted the indemnity, which consent will not be arbitrarily or unreasonably withheld or delayed

Each First Nation and their E'Dbendaagzijig and the Anishinabek Nation will be eligible to participate in and benefit from any federal programs or services in accordance with criteria for such programs or services, to the extent that the First Nation, the Anishinabek Nation or any other entity authorized by the First Nation, has not assumed responsibility for the provision of a similar program or service under the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement or other agreement with Canada.

The E'Dbendaagzijig of the First Nations who are Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Canada continue to be entitled to all the rights and benefits of other Canadian citizens or permanent residents of Canada applicable to them from time to time.
No Party will challenge the validity of any provision of this Agreement or the federal legislation that gives effect to this Agreement.
The federal legislation giving effect to this Agreement will provide for judicial notice of the laws of the First Nations and the Anishinabek Nation.

In any proceeding, including judicial proceedings, evidence of a First Nation law or an Anishinabek Nation law may be given by the production of a copy of the law, certified to be a true copy by a person authorized by that First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation respectively, without proof of that person's signature or official title.
The Anishinabek Nation is a distinct legal entity with the rights, powers and privileges of a natural person, including the legal capacity to:
enter into agreements or contracts
acquire, hold, lease or manage property or any interests therein
acquire, hold or dispose of bequests and gifts which are given to the Anishinabek Nation
sue or be sued and to act on its own behalf in legal proceedings
hold, spend, invest, raise or borrow money, and secure or guarantee the repayment of money borrowed
apply to form corporations or other legal entities in accordance with federal or provincial laws
create, operate, contribute to, or otherwise deal with trusts and act as trustee
do such other things as are ancillary to the exercise of its rights, powers and privileges under this Agreement
The Anishinabek Nation has adopted and will maintain a written constitution known as the Anishinaabe Chi-Naaknigewin.
Each First Nation will approve the Anishinaabe Chi-Naaknigewin no later than the date it ratifies this Agreement.
The Anishinaabe Chi-Naaknigewin will address, among other things:
the establishment of the Anishinabek Nation Government including institutions and structures to support the exercise of law-making powers and other authorities under this Agreement
the political and financial accountability of the Anishinabek Nation Government to the First Nations and the E'Dbendaagzijig
procedures for making, amending, publishing and providing access to Anishinabek Nation laws
delegation of authority other than law-making power
procedures for appealing or challenging the validity or application of the laws of the Anishinabek Nation
appeal and redress mechanisms
mechanisms to enact conflict of interest rules
amendment procedures

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation will exercise its law-making powers and other authorities under this Agreement through the Anishinabek Nation Government in a manner consistent with this Agreement.

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: The exercise of law-making powers and other authorities by the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement will evolve over time.

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation laws enacted under this Agreement must be in writing and available to the public.

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation will establish and maintain an official registry of its laws in English and, at the discretion of the Anishinabek Nation, in Anishinaabemowin.

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: An Anishinabek Nation law enacted under this Agreement will not be considered void, invalid or unenforceable, nor will any person's liability under an Anishinabek Nation law be affected by reason only of a defect in form or failure of the Anishinabek Nation to comply with sections 4.8 or 4.10.
The Anishinabek Nation Government will establish and maintain a repository containing official copies of the laws of the Anishinabek Nation and the First Nations enacted under this Agreement.

The Anishinabek Nation Government will provide any person with reasonable access to the repository by, among other means, posting the laws on the Anishinabek Nation Government's official website or such other electronic medium as may be available from time to time.
The Anishinabek Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the selection of the Anishinabek Nation Government representatives.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to section 4.12, the Anishinabek Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.
The Anishinabek Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the rights, privileges and responsibilities associated with being an E'Dbendaagzijig in the Anishinabek Nation.
A person who is an E'Dbendaagzijig of a First Nation is deemed to also be an E'Dbendaagzijig of the Anishinabek Nation.
The Anishinabek Nation will establish and maintain a list of all of its E'Dbendaagzijig.

In the event of a Conflict between an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to section 4.14 and a First Nation law enacted pursuant to section 5.12, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to section 4.14, the Anishinabek Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.
The Anishinabek Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the preservation, promotion and development of Anishinabek culture and languages.

In the event of a Conflict between an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to section 4.19 and a First Nation law enacted pursuant to section 5.20, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to section 4.19, the Anishinabek Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.
The Anishinabek Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the management and operation of the Anishinabek Nation Government, including laws for:
the financial administration of the Anishinabek Nation Government, including its financial accountability to its E'Dbendaagzijig
the powers, duties and responsibilities of officers, elected officials and appointees of the Anishinabek Nation Government
the establishment and management and operation of Anishinaabe Institutions
access to information and the protection of privacy
the examination, publication and scrutiny of regulations and other statutory instruments enacted by the First Nations or the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement

The Anishinabek Nation may, in the exercise of law-making power under this Agreement, make laws with respect to the personal immunity from civil liability of employees, officers, elected officials or appointees of the Anishinabek Nation Government or Anishinaabe Institutions, provided that the Anishinabek Nation Government, as employer, retains vicarious liability for acts or omissions of employees, officers, elected officials or appointees of the Anishinabek Nation Government and Anishinaabe Institutions covered by the immunity.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to sections 4.22 or 4.23, the Anishinabek Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.
An Anishinabek Nation law passed pursuant to sub-section 4.22 (d) will not provide access to personal information of a kind that is generally unavailable under federal or provincial law.

Section: Effective Date of Anishinabek Nation Law
Provision Text: Except as set out in this Agreement, an Anishinabek Nation law will come into force at the beginning of the day following its enactment or such later date as may be set out in that law.

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation may delegate any of its authorities, except its law-making powers, under this Agreement to:

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: a department or office of the Anishinabek Nation Government

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: an official identified in an Anishinabek Nation law

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text:
an Anishinaabe Institution
          or

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: any legal entity authorized by the Anishinabek Nation Government

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: The terms and conditions associated with a delegation of authority by the Anishinabek Nation under section 4.27 will be set out in writing.

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation will remain accountable to the First Nations and the E'Dbendaagzijig for the exercise of any authority it delegates.

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: The recipient of an authority delegated under section 4.27 will be accountable to the Anishinabek Nation for the exercise of that authority and may not further delegate that authority.

Section: Delegation of Authority by the Anishinabek Nation
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation may enter into an agreement to receive a delegation of law-making power or other authority.

The Anishinabek Nation will provide an opportunity to the E'Dbendaagzijig, and to any person who resides on a Reserve of a First Nation and who may be directly and significantly affected by any proposed law or Decision of the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement, to make representations about that law or Decision in accordance with the principles of procedural fairness.

An Anishinaabe Institution established by the Anishinabek Nation will provide an opportunity to the E'Dbendaagzijig, and to any person who resides on a Reserve of a First Nation and who may be directly and significantly affected by a proposed Decision of the Anishinaabe Institution, to make representations about that Decision in accordance with the principles of procedural fairness.

Where it establishes an Anishinaabe Institution, the Anishinabek Nation will provide an opportunity for the E'Dbendaagzijig, and for persons who reside on the Reserve of a First Nation and who may be directly and significantly affected by that Anishinaabe Institution, to participate in that Anishinaabe Institution. The means of participation will be set out at the time the Anishinaabe Institution is established.

Section: Appeal or Review of an Anishinabek Nation Decision
Provision Text: Where the Anishinabek Nation makes a Decision it will provide for the appeal or review of that Decision by any person who is directly and significantly affected.

Section: Appeal or Review of an Anishinabek Nation Decision
Provision Text: Where an Anishinaabe Institution is established, the Anishinabek Nation law or other authority will also provide for the appeal or review of a Decision of that Anishinaabe Institution by any person who is directly and significantly affected.

Section: Anishinaabe Institution for the Appeal or Review of a Decision
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation may establish an Anishinaabe Institution to hear the appeal or review of a Decision.
Each First Nation that ratifies this Agreement shall be a distinct legal entity with the rights, powers and privileges of a natural person, including the legal capacity to:
enter into agreements or contracts
acquire, hold, lease or manage property or any interests therein
acquire, hold or dispose of bequests and gifts which are given to that First Nation
sue or be sued and to act on its own behalf in legal proceedings
hold, spend, invest, raise or borrow money, and secure or guarantee the repayment of money borrowed
apply to form corporations or other legal entities in accordance with federal or provincial laws
create, operate, contribute to, or otherwise deal with trusts and act as trustee
do such other things as are ancillary to the exercise of its rights, powers and privileges under this Agreement
Each First Nation that ratifies this Agreement will maintain a written constitution.
Each First Nation will ratify its constitution prior to the date it ratifies this Agreement.
The constitution of each First Nation will address, among other things:
the establishment of the First Nation Government including institutions and structures to support the exercise of law-making powers and other authorities under this Agreement
the political and financial accountability of the First Nation Government to its E'Dbendaagzijig
procedures for making, amending, publishing and providing access to First Nation laws
delegation of law-making powers and other authorities
procedures for appealing or challenging the validity or application of the laws of that First Nation
appeal and redress mechanisms
mechanisms to enact conflict of interest rules
amendment procedures

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: Each First Nation that ratifies this Agreement will exercise its law-making powers and other authorities under this Agreement through its First Nation Government in a manner consistent with this Agreement.

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: The exercise of law-making powers and other authorities by a First Nation under this Agreement will evolve over time.

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: A First Nation law enacted under this Agreement must be in writing and available to the public.

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: Each First Nation that ratifies this Agreement will:

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: establish and maintain an official registry of its laws in English and, at the discretion of the First Nation, in Anishinaabemowin

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: provide a copy of each law to the Anishinabek Nation, as soon as practicable after its enactment, for inclusion in the Anishinabek Nation repository of laws

Section: Exercise of Law-Making Powers and Other Authorities
Provision Text: A First Nation law enacted under this Agreement will not be considered void, invalid or unenforceable, nor will any person's liability under a First Nation law be affected by reason only of a defect in form or failure of a First Nation to comply with section 5.8.
Each First Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the selection of its First Nation Government representatives.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and a First Nation law enacted pursuant to section 5.10, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.

Each First Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the determination of its E'Dbendaagzijig and the rights, privileges and responsibilities associated with being an E'Dbendaagzijig in the First Nation.
Each First Nation will establish and maintain a list of its E'Dbendaagzijig.

A person who is a member of a First Nation immediately prior to the coming into force of an E'Dbendaagzijig law of a First Nation enacted under this Agreement will become an E'Dbendaagzijig of that First Nation after the E'Dbendaagzijig law comes into force.

A person who was eligible to become a member of the First Nation according to the membership provisions of the Indian Act or according to the membership code of that First Nation, immediately prior to the enactment of an E'Dbendaagzijig law, will be deemed eligible to become an E'Dbendaagzijig of that First Nation, after an E'Dbendaagzijig law comes into force.

A First Nation E'Dbendaagzijig law enacted under this Agreement may not remove a person whose name is entered on a band list, as defined in the Indian Act, for that band, by reason only of a situation that existed or action taken before a First Nation E'Dbendaagzijig law comes into force.

A person entitled to be registered as an Indian under the Indian Act will continue to be entitled to be registered as an Indian under the Indian Act after an E'Dbendaagzijig law of a First Nation comes into force.

In the event of a Conflict between a First Nation law enacted pursuant to section 5.12 and an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to section 4.14, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and a First Nation law enacted pursuant to section 5.12, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.
Each First Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the preservation, promotion and development of its culture and language.

In the event of a Conflict between a First Nation law enacted pursuant to section 5.20 and an Anishinabek Nation law enacted pursuant to section 4.19, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and a First Nation law enacted pursuant to section 5.20, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.
Each First Nation has the power to enact laws with respect to the management and operation of the First Nation Government, including:
the financial administration of the First Nation Government, including its financial accountability to its E'Dbendaagzijig
the powers, duties and responsibilities of officers, elected officials and appointees of the First Nation Government
the conduct of meetings, including First Nation community meetings and First Nation council meetings
the establishment and management and operation of Anishinaabe Institutions
access to information and the protection of privacy

A First Nation may, in the exercise of law-making power under this Agreement, make laws with respect to the personal immunity from civil liability of employees, officers, elected officials or appointees of the First Nation Government or Anishinaabe Institutions, provided that the First Nation Government, as employer, retains vicarious liability for acts or omissions of employees, officers, elected officials or appointees of the First Nation Government and Anishinaabe Institutions covered by the immunity.

Except as set out in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between a federal law and a First Nation law enacted pursuant to sections 5.23 or 5.24, the First Nation law will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.
A law of a First Nation passed pursuant to sub-section 5.23(e) will not provide access to personal information of a kind that is generally unavailable under federal or provincial law.

Section: Effective Date of a First Nation Law
Provision Text: Except as set out in this Agreement, a law of a First Nation will come into force at the beginning of the day following its enactment or such later date as may be set out in that law.

Section: Delegation of Law-Making Powers by a First Nation
Provision Text: Each First Nation may delegate, in whole or in part, a law-making power under this Agreement to the Anishinabek Nation.

Section: Delegation of Law-Making Powers by a First Nation
Provision Text: The terms and conditions associated with a delegation of law-making power by a First Nation under section 5.28 will be set out in writing.

Section: Delegation of Law-Making Powers by a First Nation
Provision Text: The First Nation will remain accountable to its E'Dbendaagzijig for the exercise of any law-making power it delegates.

Section: Delegation of Law-Making Powers by a First Nation
Provision Text: The Anishinabek Nation will be accountable to the First Nation for the exercise of a law-making power delegated to it under section 5.28 and may not further delegate that law-making power.

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: Each First Nation may delegate any of its authorities, under this Agreement to:

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: a department or office of the First Nation Government

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: an official identified in a First Nation law

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: the Anishinabek Nation

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text:
an Anishinaabe Institution
          or

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: any legal entity authorized by the First Nation

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: The terms and conditions associated with a delegation of authority by the First Nation under section 5.32 will be set out in writing.

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: The First Nation will remain accountable to its E'Dbendaagzijig for the exercise of any authority it delegates.

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: The recipient of an authority delegated under section 5.32 will be accountable to the First Nation for the exercise of that authority and may not further delegate that authority.

Section: Delegation of Authority by a First Nation
Provision Text: A First Nation may enter into an agreement to receive a delegation of authority.

Each First Nation will provide an opportunity to its E'Dbendaagzijig, and to any person who resides on the Reserve of that First Nation and who may be directly and significantly affected by any proposed law or Decision of that First Nation under this Agreement, to make representations about that law or Decision in accordance with the principles of procedural fairness.

An Anishinaabe Institution established by a First Nation will provide an opportunity to E'Dbendaagzijig, and to any person who resides on the Reserve of that First Nation and who may be directly and significantly affected by a proposed Decision of the Anishinaabe Institution, to make representations about that Decision in accordance with the principles of procedural fairness.

Where it establishes an Anishinaabe Institution, a First Nation will provide an opportunity for its E'Dbendaagzijig, and for persons who reside on the Reserve of that First Nation and who may be directly and significantly affected by that Anishinaabe Institution, to participate in that Anishinaabe Institution. The means of participation will be set out at the time the Anishinaabe Institution is established.

Section: Appeal or Review of a First Nation Decision
Provision Text: Where a First Nation makes a Decision it will provide for the appeal or review of that Decision by any person who is directly and significantly affected.

Section: Appeal or Review of a First Nation Decision
Provision Text: Where an Anishinaabe Institution is established, a First Nation law or other authority will also provide for the appeal or review of a Decision of that Anishinaabe Institution by any person who is directly and significantly affected.

Section: Anishinaabe Institution for the Appeal or Review of a First Nation Decision
Provision Text: A First Nation may establish an Anishinaabe Institution to hear the appeal or review of a Decision made by that First Nation or by any of its Anishinaabe Institutions.

Each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation may provide services, including restorative justice or mediation services, for the voluntary settlement of disputes arising from the exercise of its law-making powers and other authorities under this Agreement.

Each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation may establishtraditional Anishinaabe processes, and impose Anishinaabe sanctions as set out in section 6.4, to deal with alleged offences under First Nation or Anishinabek Nation laws under this Agreement.

Subject to section 6.4, the laws of each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement, may provide for the creation of offences and for the imposition of sanctions, including fines, penalties and imprisonment for the violation of those laws.

As an alternative to fines, penalties or imprisonment described in section 6.3, the laws of each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement may provide for Anishinaabe sanctions that are consistent with Anishinaabe customs, culture, traditions and values, provided that such sanctions are proportionate to the seriousness of the offence and are not imposed on an offender without his or her consent.

Where the law of a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation provides for the imposition of a fine or a term of imprisonment for the violation of that law, the sanction will not be greater than those imposed under the general penalty provisions of the Criminal Code that apply to offences punishable on summary convictions or $10,000, whichever is greater.

Each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation may provide for the enforcement of its laws under this Agreement and may appoint enforcement officers with powers of enforcement comparable to those provided by the laws of Ontario or Canada for officers enforcing similar laws.

Each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation is responsible for the prosecution of violations of its laws and may appoint individuals to conduct such prosecutions in a manner consistent with the principles of prosecutorial independence.
Each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation may adopt procedures for the enforcement of their laws and prosecution of offences.
The procedures adopted pursuant to section 6.8 may include, with necessary modifications:

the procedures for the prosecution of offences under the Ontario Provincial Offences Act
          or
the summary conviction procedures of Part XXVII of the Criminal Code
Every fine or penalty arising out of the adjudication of a law of a First Nation will be remitted to and belong to that First Nation.
Every fine or penalty arising out of the adjudication of an Anishinabek Nation law will be remitted to and belong to the Anishinabek Nation.

The Federal Court of Canada has jurisdiction with respect to applications for judicial review of a Decision, provided all procedures for appeal or review applicable to that Decision have been exhausted.
The Ontario Court of Justice has jurisdiction to hear prosecutions of offences under the laws of each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement.

The Ontario Court of Justice has jurisdiction with respect to matters arising under the laws of each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation if those matters are within the jurisdiction of the Ontario Court of Justice under federal or provincial law dealing with the same subject matter.
The Ontario Superior Court of Justice has jurisdiction to hear and determine:

proceedings for civil matters under the laws of each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation if those matters are within the jurisdiction of the Superior Court of Justice under federal or provincial law dealing with the same subject matter
appeals of decisions of the Ontario Court of Justice with respect to matters referred to in section 6.13 and 6.14
The Parties affirm that they are committed to a new government-to-government relationship based on openness, cooperation and mutual respect.
The Parties will establish the Anishinabek Nation - Canada Intergovernmental Forum to maintain their intergovernmental relationship and to enable cooperation on issues of mutual interest or concern.
The initial terms of reference for the operation of the Intergovernmental Forum are set out in Schedule B.
The Parties will maintain a financial relationship and fiscal arrangements consistent with this Agreement.
The Parties acknowledge that the financing of the new government to government financial relationship is a shared responsibility of the Anishinabek Nation Government and Canada.

The creation of the Anishinabek Nation Government, the recognition of the Anishinabek Nation Government's legislative authority under this Agreement or the exercise of the Anishinabek Nation Government's legislative authority does not create or imply any financial obligation or service delivery obligation on the part of any Party.

The Parties acknowledge that the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement is a part of the new government to government financial relationship and sets out financial obligations applicable to both Parties.

The Parties have negotiated an Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement that sets out the responsibilities and commitments of the First Nations, the Anishinabek Nation, and Canada with respect to the financial arrangements to support this Agreement.
The Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement is a contract between Canada and the Anishinabek Nation on its own behalf and on behalf of the First Nations.

The Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement is not a treaty within the meaning of section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982 and does not abrogate or derogate from the Aboriginal or treaty rights of the Aboriginal peoples of Canada recognized and affirmed by section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982.
The Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement:
does not form part of this Agreement
does not alter any rights or obligations under this Agreement
will not be used to interpret this Agreement
will be interpreted in a manner that is consistent with this Agreement
On the Effective Date, the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement will:
set out Federally Supported Programs and Services and one -time implementation activities
set out the term of the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement and the process for concluding subsequent fiscal agreements
set out procedures for calculating Transfer Payments
set out the timing of Transfer Payments
set out a methodology for adjusting the Transfer Payment, including changes in price and volume
set out procedures for addressing general funding increases
set out the process for addressing any extraordinary circumstance
set out accountability requirements
set out administrative procedures

set out procedures for the collection, exchange and verification of information, including statistical and financial information, required for the administration of the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement
identify the dispute resolution mechanism
set out amendment procedures
set out an approach for amalgamating the fiscal agreements for the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement and this Anishinabek Nation Governance Agreement
set out other matters agreed to by the Parties
The formula for calculating the First Nations' Fiscal Contribution will be set out in the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement.
The following types of revenues will be excluded from the First Nations' Fiscal Contribution formula:
amounts received by a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation as a gift or donation

amounts received by a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation from the
          Crown concerning a settlement, court order or a decision of an adjudicative body, as compensation for past, ongoing or potential infringements of any rights under section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982
proceeds to any First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation from the sale or expropriation of First Nation or Anishinabek Nation lands
any other revenue sources as agreed to in writing by the Parties

For greater certainty, funding received by a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation for expenditure on programs and services from a federal or provincial source will be excluded from the First Nations' Fiscal Contribution formula.

Section: Transition from Existing Funding Arrangements to the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement
Provision Text: On the Effective Date, any funding provided by Canada to each First Nation in relevant funding agreements that precede the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement for programs and services which are similar to the Federally Supported Programs and Services will be replaced by the Transfer Payment.
The Transfer Payment is subject to the appropriation of funds by the Parliament of Canada.
For greater certainty, any unexpended Transfer Payment will not be returned to Canada.
Each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation will prepare financial statements and reports in accordance with the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement and Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.

The Transfer Payment will not be subject to the Default Prevention Management Policy or any successor policy of the Department of Crown-Indigenous Relations and Northern Affairs or any successor department.

Section: Future Treatment of a Model Fiscal Chapter
Provision Text: Canada will give notice to the Anishinabek Nation if, prior to the fifth anniversary of the Effective Date, Canada approves a revised model fiscal chapter for general use in modern treaty and self-government negotiations.

Section: Future Treatment of a Model Fiscal Chapter
Provision Text: Within 2 years after the receipt of a notice from Canada, the Anishinabek Nation may propose amendments to this Chapter based on the revised model fiscal chapter referred to in section 8.18.

Section: Future Treatment of a Model Fiscal Chapter
Provision Text: Within 6 months after the date the Anishinabek Nation proposes amendments, the Parties will commence negotiations with a view to reaching agreement on amendments to this Agreement that replace this Chapter with a revised chapter that is based upon the revised model fiscal chapter.

Section: Future Treatment of a Model Fiscal Chapter
Provision Text: Should the Parties agree on amendments to this Chapter further to the negotiations referred to in section 8.20, the Parties will give effect to those amendments in accordance with Chapter 14.

Canada will recommend to Parliament amendments to the Access to Information Act and the Privacy Act to protect from disclosure, information provided in confidence by a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation as if it were information provided to Canada by another government in Canada.

Canada will recommend to Parliament amendments to the Privacy Act to allow a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation access to information necessary for a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation to exercise its law-making powers and other authorities under this Agreement.

A First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation may enter into agreements with Canada or 1 another in respect of the collection, protection, retention, use, disclosure or confidentiality of data and information.

Canada may provide information to a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation, in confidence, provided the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation has enacted a law for the protection of confidential information or has entered into an agreement with Canada for the protection of confidential information.
Canada is not required to disclose information that is required to be withheld under a federal law.
The Parties are not required to disclose information that may be withheld under a privilege at law.

Each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation will develop and maintain a system to provide E'Dbendaagzijig with access to information held by the First Nation Government, the Anishinabek Nation Government and Anishinaabe Institutions.

In developing exemptions to access to information, each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation will be guided by the exemptions contained in existing access to information and privacy legislation in Canada.

The council of a First Nation who hold office on the Effective Date will be the Ogiimah and council of a First Nation and will continue to hold office until such time as the First Nation selects its representatives under its leadership selection law.
Until a First Nation enacts a leadership selection law under this Agreement, the election procedures that apply on the Effective Date will continue to apply.

Until a First Nation enacts an E'Dbendaagzijig law under this Agreement, the membership provisions of the Indian Act or the membership code of the First Nation that applies on the Effective Date will continue to apply.

The Grand Council Ogiimah, the Deputy Grand Council Ogiimak and the Ogiimak of the First Nations of the Anishinabek Nation will be the Grand Council until the Anishinabek Nation selects its representatives under its leadership selection law.
Except as provided for in sections 10.6, 10.7 and 10.8, on the Effective Date, the Indian Act will continue to apply to each First Nation, its E'Dbendaagzijig and its Reserve.
When a First Nation's E'Dbendaagzijig law enacted pursuant to section 5.12 comes into force, sections 8 to 14 of the Indian Act will no longer apply.
When a First Nation's leadership selection law enacted pursuant to section 5.10 comes into force, sections 74 to 79 of the Indian Act will no longer apply.
On the Effective Date section 80 of the Indian Act will no longer apply.

For the purposes of the continuing application of the Indian Act, a First Nation will be a "band", the Ogiimah and council of a First Nation Government will be the "council of the band" and an E'Dbendaagzijig will be a "member of a band", as those terms are defined in the Indian Act.
As soon as practicable after the Effective Date, each First Nation will enact:
a leadership selection law
an E'Dbendaagzijig law
a financial administration law
As soon as practicable after the Effective Date, the Anishinabek Nation will enact:
a leadership selection law
a financial administration law

Section: Application of First Nations Land Management Act
Provision Text: The First Nations Land Management Act will continue to apply to a First Nation who has a land code in force under the First Nations Land Management Act.

Section: Application of First Nations Land Management Act
Provision Text: Except as provided for in this Agreement, in the event of a Conflict between the First Nations Land Management Act and this Agreement, this Agreement will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.

Section: Application of First Nations Elections Act
Provision Text: When a First Nation's leadership selection law enacted pursuant to section 5.10 comes into force, the First Nations Elections Act will no longer apply to that First Nation.
The laws of each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation enacted under this Agreement operate concurrently with federal and provincial laws, unless otherwise provided for in this Agreement.
Federal laws apply to each First Nation, its Government, its Anishinaabe Institutions, its Reserve and all persons on its Reserve, unless otherwise provided for in this Agreement.
Federal laws apply to the Anishinabek Nation, its Government and its Anishinaabe Institutions, unless otherwise provided for in this Agreement.
For greater certainty, the law-making powers of each First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement do not extend to matters not specifically addressed in this Agreement, including:
criminal law or criminal procedure
labour relations and working conditions
Intellectual Property

aeronautics, navigation and shipping
          or
the official languages of Canada

Any applicable provincial laws continue to apply to each First Nation, its Government, its Anishinaabe Institutions, its Reserve and all persons on its Reserve unless otherwise provided for in this Agreement.
Any applicable provincial laws apply to the Anishinabek Nation, its Government and its Anishinaabe Institutions, unless otherwise provided for in this Agreement.

Notwithstanding any other provision in this Agreement, a federal law in relation to peace, order and good government, criminal law, the protection of the health and safety of all Canadians, the protection of human rights or other matters of overriding national importance, prevails to the extent of a Conflict with a law of a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement.

A federal or provincial law prevails to the extent of a Conflict with a provision of a First Nation law or an Anishinabek Nation law under this Agreement that has a double aspect with, or an incidental impact on, a subject matter for which the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation:

has no law-making power under this Agreement
          or
has law-making power under this Agreement but in respect of which this Agreement sets out that a federal or provincial law would prevail in the event of a Conflict
In the event of a Conflict between the federal legislation giving effect to this Agreement and this Agreement, this Agreement prevails to the extent of the Conflict.
In the event of a Conflict between a federal law and this Agreement, this Agreement prevails to the extent of the Conflict.

In the event of a Conflict between the federal legislation giving effect to this Agreement and any other federal law, the federal legislation giving effect to this Agreement prevails to the extent of the Conflict.

Prior to expressing consent to be bound by an International Treaty which would give rise to a new International Legal Obligation, compliance with which may adversely affect a right of a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement, Canada will consult with the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation with respect to the International Legal Obligation, either separately or through a forum that Canada determines is appropriate.

Where Canada informs a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation that a law or other exercise of authority of that First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement will adversely affect Canada's ability to comply with an International Legal Obligation, that First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation and Canada will discuss how the law or other exercise of authority could be modified so that Canada is able to comply with the International Legal Obligation.

Where Canada's compliance with an International Legal Obligation is under consideration by an International Tribunal as a result of a law or other exercise of authority of a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement, Canada will notify the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation. Further, Canada and that First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation will discuss the development of the position to be taken by Canada before the International Tribunal regarding the law or other exercise of authority of the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation. If requested by Canada, the First Nation and the Anishinabek Nation will assist Canada in the preparation of Canada's position, including by providing documents and witnesses in relation to the law or other exercise of authority of the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation. The specific means of participation will be discussed by Canada and the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation.

If there is a finding by an International Tribunal of non-compliance by Canada with an International Legal Obligation attributable to a law or other exercise of authority of a First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation under this Agreement, the First Nation or the Anishinabek Nation will, at the request of Canada, take such measures as may be necessary to enable Canada to comply with the International Legal Obligation.

Section: Relationship Between this Governance Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement
Provision Text: This Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement are intended to operate concurrently.

Section: Relationship Between this Governance Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement
Provision Text: A First Nation that is a party to this Agreement and to the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement will exercise its law-making powers and other authorities under the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement through its First Nation Government.

Section: Relationship Between this Governance Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement
Provision Text: As soon as practicable after the Effective Date, the Participating First Nations of the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement and the First Nations and the Anishinabek Nation who are party to this Agreement will:

Section: Relationship Between this Governance Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement
Provision Text: address education and operational matters, including representation within the structures of the Anishinabek Nation Government

Section: Relationship Between this Governance Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement
Provision Text: take measures to avoid the duplication of activities, functions and processes relating to the implementation of this Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement

Section: Relationship Between this Governance Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement
Provision Text: In the event of a Conflict between this Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Agreement, this Agreement will prevail to the extent of the Conflict.

The first subsequent Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement will amalgamate the fiscal agreements for this Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Education Fiscal Transfer Agreement into a single fiscal agreement.

The Parties may agree to negotiate additional self-government agreements to recognize the exercise of law-making powers or other authorities by the First Nations or the Anishinabek Nation in areas not addressed in this Agreement, including:
social services
administration of justice
health
lands and natural resource management
labour and training
marriage
divorce
economic development including, the licensing, regulation and operation of businesses
public works and infrastructure
housing
Indian monies
wills and estates
emergency preparedness
taxation
local traffic and transportation
environmental protection, conservation and assessment
policing
any other matters agreed to by the Parties

When any Party seeks to negotiate a self-government agreement contemplated by section 13.1, that Party will notify the other Parties, and, where there is an agreement to negotiate, the Parties will meet as soon as is practicable to commence the negotiations.
In the negotiation of a self-government agreement pursuant to section 13.1, the Parties will:
negotiate in good faith

provide to 1 another, in a timely manner, policy, research, program information or documentation that is relevant to the negotiation of the agreement, except that which the Parties are not required to disclose under the exercise of any privilege or any law
jointly undertake to seek ways and means to address the resource requirements in order to ensure that each Party effectively participates in the negotiation of the agreement
use reasonable efforts to build consensus and to focus the negotiations on common interests
participate as full and equal partners
take into consideration gender equity and other factors, including race and ethnicity, religion, age and mental or physical disability
negotiate with 1 another based on the principle of mutual respect
Any agreement concluded pursuant to section 13.1, will include, among other things:
a description of the law-making powers or other authorities to be exercised by the First Nations or the Anishinabek Nation
rules to govern the relationship between laws
the identification of any provisions of the Indian Act or other legislation that will no longer apply
any other matter agreed to by the Parties
Except as agreed to in writing by the Parties, a self-government agreement negotiated pursuant to section 13.1 will be part of this Agreement and will be added as a Schedule to this Agreement.

Prior to the approval of future self-government agreements negotiated pursuant to section 13.1, the Anishinabek Nation Government and Canada will negotiate such amendments as may be required to this Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement.
The Parties agree that subject matters for future negotiations that may affect areas of provincial jurisdiction may require the participation of Ontario.

Section: Non-Substantive Amendments Prior to Effective Date
Provision Text: Following the ratification of this Agreement by the First Nations, but prior to the Effective Date, the Parties may agree in writing to non-substantive amendments to this Agreement, without a requirement for ratification of these amendments by the First Nations.
This Agreement may only be amended in writing by the Parties.
The consent to any amendment will be effected in the following order:
in the case of the First Nations and the Anishinabek Nation, by a Grand Council Resolution passed by a majority of the First Nations
in the case of Canada, by order of the Governor-in-Council and, if required, the enactment of federal legislation giving effect to the amendment
An amendment to this Agreement takes effect on a date agreed to in writing by the Parties.

Section: Addition of a First Nation as a Party after the Effective Date
Provision Text: Subject to section 14.6, this Agreement may be amended to include a First Nation who is not a Party to this Agreement as of the Effective Date.

Section: Addition of a First Nation as a Party after the Effective Date
Provision Text: A First Nation seeking to be a Party to this Agreement will be required to follow the ratification process set out in sections 15.2 to 15.7.

Section: Addition of a First Nation as a Party after the Effective Date
Provision Text: Prior to the ratification of this Agreement by a First Nation referred to in section 14.5, the Parties will negotiate such amendments as may be required to the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement or take any necessary steps to add a First Nation as a Party to this Agreement.
In this Chapter and in the ratification protocol and any voting guidelines, "Eligible Voter" means a person:
who is at least 18 years of age by the last day of voting period

whose name appears on the "band list" as defined in the Indian Act of a First Nation that is participating in a ratification vote or who is entitled to have their name appear on the "band list" of that First Nation
The process to be used by each First Nation to ratify this Agreement is set out in the ratification protocol and will be guided by, among other things, the following principles:
openness and transparency
opportunities for Eligible Voters of a First Nation to participate in the ratification of the Agreement
access to information
Prior to the ratification vote being conducted, each First Nation will take reasonable steps to inform its Eligible Voters of:
their right to vote and how that right can be exercised
this Agreement, the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement and the Implementation Plan
A vote by secret ballot shall be held among all Eligible Voters on the Ballot question defined as follows:
As a Voter of the (First Nation Name), do you:
approve the proposed Anishinabek Nation Governance Agreement and authorize the Ogiimah and council to execute the Agreement?
Yes ( )
No ( )
Ratification of this Agreement requires a minimum of 25% plus 1 of a First Nation's Eligible Voters vote "Yes" and those who vote "Yes" represent a majority of those who voted

Notwithstanding section 15.5, where the minimum of 25% plus 1 is not achieved but a majority of those who voted, voted "Yes", the First Nation may call a second vote within a timeframe agreed to by the Parties:
where there are more "Yes" votes than "No" votes in the second vote, the First Nation is deemed to have ratified this Agreement pursuant to this Chapter
the ratification protocol will apply to the second vote with necessary modifications as agreed to by the Parties

The Parties will establish a Ratification Committee consisting of 1 individual appointed by the First Nations and 1 individual appointed by Canada unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the Parties.
The Ratification Committee will oversee the conduct of the ratification process set out in the protocol.
The Parties will determine the procedures and rules for the Ratification Committee to implement the ratification vote, which shall be in accordance with the principles of natural justice.

Section: Communicating Results of the First Nations' Votes
Provision Text: Prior to the ratification vote, the Parties will prepare a joint communications strategy for how the results of the ratification votes will be shared.

Section: Communicating Results of the First Nations' Votes
Provision Text: As soon as practicable after the last day of the ratification vote, the Ratification Committee will provide a written report to the Parties setting out the official results of each First Nation's ratification vote.

Section: Communicating Results of the First Nations' Votes
Provision Text: The authorized representatives of the Anishinabek Nation and Canada will meet within 21 days after the ratification vote to discuss any implications and any further course of action.
Following ratification by the First Nations, a Minister authorised to do so will seek the approval to:
sign this Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement
introduce legislation in Parliament to give effect to this Agreement
Canada will have ratified this Agreement when the federal legislation giving legal effect to this Agreement comes into force.
Canada will pay the costs associated with the ratification of this Agreement in an amount agreed upon by the Anishinabek Nation and Canada prior to the commencement of the ratification process.
Canada will consult with the First Nations in the preparation of the federal legislation by providing:
drafts of the legislation
a reasonable opportunity for the First Nations to present their comments on the draft legislation
a timely written response to any comments received from the First Nations
Canada will consult with the Anishinabek Nation on any future amendments that may be required to the federal legislation that gives effect to this Agreement.
Except as agreed to in writing by the Parties, future self-government agreements will be approved in accordance with this Agreement.
The Parties are committed to implementing this Agreement by carrying out their respective obligations under this Agreement.
The Parties will share, in a timely manner, data and information reasonably required for purposes of implementing and monitoring this Agreement.
To guide the implementation of this Agreement the Parties have developed an Implementation Plan.
The term of the Implementation Plan is 10 years from the Effective Date and may be extended for an additional period as agreed to in writing by the Anishinabek Nation and Canada.
The Implementation Plan:
identifies the obligations of the Parties in this Agreement
identifies the activities to be undertaken to fulfill those obligations and the responsible Party
identifies the time frame for the completion of implementation activities
addresses other matters agreed to by the Parties
The Implementation Plan:
does not form part of this Agreement
is not a contract between the Parties
is not a treaty within the meaning of section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982
does not alter any rights or obligations under this Agreement
will not create legal obligations that are binding on the Parties
will not be used to limit or interpret this Agreement
will not preclude any Party from asserting that other obligations exist under this Agreement even though they are not set out in the Implementation Plan

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: On the Effective Date, the Implementation and Operations Committee will be established comprised of 3 representatives: 1 for Canada, 1 for the First Nations and 1 for the Anishinabek Nation.

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: The Implementation and Operations Committee will:

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: monitor and assess the implementation of this Agreement and the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: identify any implementation issues and provide advice and recommendations to the Parties on ways implementation can be strengthened including whether any amendments to this Agreement or the Anishinabek Nation Fiscal Agreement should be considered

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: attempt to resolve implementation issues informally, to prevent or minimize disputes

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: meet at the request of a Party to assess impacts and recommend steps that may be taken to address a situation where a Party may be unable to meet an obligation under this Agreement

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: amend the Implementation Plan by agreement in writing

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: ensure that an annual update on the implementation of this Agreement is prepared

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: establish the procedures and rules to govern its operation

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: establish working groups asrequired

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: make decisions byunanimous agreement

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: meet annually or more often as required

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: seek advice or support as required

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: operate for the term of the Implementation Plan or any other period agreed to in writing by the Anishinabek Nation and Canada

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: address any other matters as agreed to by the Parties

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: Each Party is responsible for its own costs of participation in the Implementation and Operations Committee.

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: Canada will make the annual update provided for in sub-section 16.8(f) publicly available.

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: In the year prior to the expiry of the first Implementation Plan, the Implementation and Operations Committee will make recommendations to the Parties on:

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: whether the activities set out in the Implementation Plan have been completed

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: whether the Implementation Plan should be extended

Section: Establishment and Role of the Implementation and Operations Committee
Provision Text: any on-going role for the Implementation and Operations Committee
In this Chapter, "parties to the dispute" means:

1 or more First Nations and Canada
          or

the Anishinabek Nation and Canada
          or
1 or more First Nations and the Anishinabek Nation and Canada

The Parties will use best efforts to prevent or minimize disputes in relation tothe interpretation, application or implementation of this Agreement, including disputes, which may affect the delivery of Federally Supported Programs and Services.
Where the best efforts to prevent a dispute are not successful, the parties to the dispute agree to:
identify and resolve the dispute as quickly and as cost-effectively as practicable
participate in good faith in the dispute resolution processes set out in this Chapter
Except as provided for in this Agreement and prior to referring a dispute to a court, a dispute will progress through the following stages until resolved:
initial written notice of the matter in dispute pursuant to section 17.9
collaborative negotiations pursuant to section 17.10
mediation pursuant to sections 17.11 to 17.14
arbitration pursuant to sections 17.16 to 17.19
Where a dispute is resolved pursuant to this Chapter, the resolution will be:
in writing
signed by authorized representatives of the parties to the dispute
delivered to the parties to the dispute
binding on the parties to the dispute

All communications or documents concerning a dispute will be "without prejudice" and the parties to the dispute will treat all communications or documents related to the dispute as confidential, unless otherwise agreed to in writing.
Where the parties to the dispute agree, a time frame set out in this Chapter may be amended.
The Implementation and Operations Committee may develop and maintain a roster of qualified mediators and arbitrators.

Where a dispute has not been resolved informally, a party to the dispute may initiate dispute resolution by delivering a written notice of the dispute to the other parties to the dispute. Such notice will identify:
